"Little Red Riding <Hood::nn/>" is a/an <beloved::jj/> fairy tale for young children.
It is a story about a/an <young::jj/> girl and a wolf.
The girl's mother sends her to take <food::food/> to her sick grandmother.
The mother tells her she must not <stop::vb/> on the way.
A wolf sees the girl walking through the <woods::nns/> and makes a plan to <eat::vb/> her.
The wolf <politely::rb/> asks the girl where she is going.
The girl <answers::vbz/> him, because he seems <friendly::jj/>.
Then the wolf tells her to pick some <flowers::nns/> for her grandmother.
While she is <picking::vbg/> flowers, the wolf goes to her grandmother's house and eats her.
He puts on the grandmother's <night-cap::nn/> and gets into her bed.
When the girl arrives at her grandmother's house, she gets into <bed::nn/> with the wolf.
The wolf leaps upon the child and <eats::vbz/> her.

Spider-Man has been one of the most <popular::jj/> and commercially successful <superheroes::nns/>.
His real name is Peter Parker, a high school student who <frequently::rb/> suffered rejection, inadequacy, and <loneliness::nn/> that most young readers could <easily::rb/> relate to.
He is an orphan being <raised::vbn/> by his Aunt May and Uncle Ben.
He would later learn that "with great <power::nn/> comes great <responsibility::nn/>" - a quote that he would cherish from his dying Uncle Ben.
One day, he is <bitten::vbn/> by a/an radioactive spider on his <neck::body/> which gives him his <powers::nns/> that turn him to Spider-Man.
His powers are <super::jj/> strength, agility, the ability to cling to almost every <surface::nn/> and to shoot spider webs from his <hands::body/> using a device that he <invented::vbd/>.
He can also react to danger <quickly::rb/> with his "spider-sense".

A rock concert is a musical <performance::nn/> in the style of any one of many genres inspired by "rock and <roll::vb/>" music.
While a variety of vocal and <instrumental::jj/> styles can constitute a rock concert, this phenomenon is typically characterized by <bands::nns/> playing at least one <electric::jj/> guitar, an electric bass guitar, and <drums::nns/>.
Often, two <guitar::nn/> players share the <tasks::nns/> of rhythm and lead guitar playing.
The coining of the <phrase::nn/> "rock and roll" is often attributed to Alan Freed, a disk jockey and concert promoter who <organized::vbd/> many of the first major rock <concerts::nns/>.
Bill Graham is widely credited with <setting::vbg/> the format and <standards::nns/> for modern rock concerts.
He introduced advance ticketing, introduced <modern::jj/> security measures and had <clean::jj/> toilets and safe conditions in large venues.

Kimberly Kardashian is a/an <American::jj/> socialite.
She used to be a/an <model::nn/>.
She is one of the three <daughters::nns/> of Robert Kardashian.
Her family has a reality <television::nn/> series called "Keeping up with the <Kardashians::nns/>".
Kim and her <sister::nn/> Kourtney have their own spin-off "Kourtney and Kim <Take::vb/> New York".
Kardashian was originally known for the <media attention::nn/> she got because of her close friendship with Paris Hilton.
She later gained some <fame::nn/> after appearing in a/an <sex::jj/> tape.
Kim married Damon Thomas in 2000 and <divorced::vbd/> Damon Thomas in 2004.
She then married Kris Humphries in August 2011 who is a/an <NBA::nn/> player on the New Jersey <Nets::nns/>.
After 72 days of marriage, she filed for a divorce on October because of <differences::nns/>.
She became <engaged::vbn/> to Kanye West in 2013.
The couple live in Beverly Hills with their daughter and <son::nn/>.

The duck-billed platypus is a/an <small::jj/> mammal that <lives::vbz/> in eastern Australia.
It lives in <rivers::nns/> and on river banks.
It is a mammal which <lays::vbz/> eggs.
Although the platypus was first <described::vbn/> in the early 19th century, it took a while before <biologists::nns/> in England believed what they were <reading::vbg/>.
The platypus looks similar to a/an <beaver::animal/> with a furry, <brown::jj/> body and wide, flat <tail::body/>.
Unlike a/an <beaver::animal/>, the platypus has no <feet::body/>, which are good for swimming.
Its nose is large and <rubbery::jj/>, similar to a duck's bill (mouth). 
The male platypus has a sharp spine on his two back legs which contain a/an <poison::nn/> that will not kill humans, but the poison has been known to <kill::vb/> small animals, such as <dogs::animal_plural/>, and cause <pain::nn/> lasting as long as four months.

Kangaroos hop to move around <quickly::rb/>, and walk on four legs while moving slowly.
They can jump <backwards::rb/>, but only a very <small::jj/> distance.
The kangaroo is a herbivore, eating mainly <grass:::food/>, but some species also eat <shrubs:::food_plural/>.
Kangaroos are marsupials because they <carry::vb/> their young in a/an <special::jj/> pouch on their bodies.
Because kangaroos are mostly found in Australia, Australians see them as a/an <national::jj/> symbol.
The kangaroo is featured <holding::vbg/> the Australian coat of arms.
The Australian <airline::nn/>, Qantas, uses the kangaroo as its emblem.
Kangaroos can be <dangerous::jj/> because of their powerful <legs:::body_plural/>.
They can lean back on their <tails:::body_plural/> to deliver powerful kicks.
In 2009, a man went to save his dog which had <chased::vbd/> a kangaroo into a farm dam.
The kangaroo gave the man several big <kicks::nns/> before he was able to grab his dog and escape from the dam.

The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is the world's <biggest::jj/> and most powerful <particle::nn/> accelerator.
It is a giant circular <tunnel::nn/> built underground.
10,000 scientists and <engineers::nns/> from over 100 different <countries::nns/> worked together in the making of this <project::nn/>, and it cost 10.4 billion Swiss francs to build.
It is now the largest and most <complicated::jj/> experimental research facility in the <world::nn/>.
The Large Hadron Collider gained a considerable amount of <attention::nn/> from outside the <scientific::jj/> community and its progress is followed by most <popular::jj/> science media.
The LHC has also inspired works of fiction including novels, TV series, <video::nn/> games and <films::nns/>.
Some people think the LHC would create a/an <black::jj/> hole, which would be very <dangerous::jj/>, but there are many reasons not to be worried.

Pizza is a type of <food::nn/> that was created in Italy.
It is made by putting "toppings" such as cheese, sausages, <pepperoni::food/>, vegetables, tomatoes, <spices::food/> and herbs over a piece of <bread::nn/> covered with sauce; most often tomato, but sometimes <butter::nn/>-based sauces are used.
Modern pizza <evolved::vbd/> from similar <flatbread dishes::nns/> in Naples about 200 years ago.
Pizza was brought to the United States with Italian <immigrants::nns/> in the late nineteenth century.
The country's <first::jj/> pizzeria, Lombardi's, opened in 1905.
Since then pizza consumption has <exploded::vbd/> in the U.S.
Thirteen percent of the U.S. population <eats::vbz/> pizza on any given day.
In the 20th century, pizza has become a/an <international::jj/> food and the <toppings::nns/> may be quite different in accordance with local tastes.
Pizzas can also be made without <meat::nn/> for vegetarians, and without <cheese::nn/> for vegans.

Fax is the <transmission::nn/> of scanned printed <material::nn/> to a telephone number connected to a printer.
The original document is scanned with a/an <fax machine::nn/>, which turns the contents into a/an <bitmap::nn/>.
Then the <bitmap::nn/> is sent through the <telephone::nn/> system.
The receiving fax machine <reconverts::vbz/> the coded image, printing a paper copy.
Businesses usually have fax system, but the technology has faced increasing competition from <Internet::nn/>-based methods.
Fax machines still retain some advantages, particularly in the transmission of <sensitive::jj/> material which, if sent over the Internet, may be intercepted.
In many businesses, fax machines have been replaced by fax servers which receive and store incoming faxes <electronically::rb/>.
Such systems <reduce::vb/> costs by eliminating <unnecessary::jj/> printouts and reducing the number of <inbound::jj/> phone lines needed by an office.

Wise spelunkers <explore::vb/> in groups to prevent being lost or stranded in a/an <cave::nn/>.
Spelunkers need reliable <equipment::nn/>, because the descent into a/an <cave::nn/> is like mountain climbing in the opposite direction.
Basic spelunking equipment is similar to what <mountain::nn/> climbers use.
Strong <ropes::nns/> make climbing possible and <special::jj/> tools attach ropes to cave walls.
Special <footwear::nn/> makes it easier to explore hard to reach places, and <hard::jj/> hats protect spelunkers from the falling <rocks::nns/> above.
Caves are extremely <dark::jj/>, so spelunkers have to <carry::vb/> at least three light sources.
Caves are also very <cold::jj/>, so most spelunkers wear <heavy::jj/> clothing for warmth.

On 1903, the Wright brothers Orville and Wilbur, designed, built, and <flew::vbd/> the first controlled, powered, heavier-than-<air::nn/> airplane.
The brothers had been <experimenting::vbg/> for many years with <gliders::nns/> and other vehicles before their <first::jj/> powered flight.
The Wrights started working on <making::vbg/> airplanes in their <bicycle::nn/> shop.
They thought controlling a/an <plane::nn/> was one of the big problems of <flight::nn/>.
The Wright brothers <fixed::vbd/> the problem by building <wings::nns/> that could be twisted a little and moved up and down slightly.
The Wright Flyer <airplane::nn/> first flew <successfully::rb/> on December 1903, in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
This was the first time <people::animal_plural/> ever flew a powered airplane they could <control::vb/>.

Shot put is a/an <great::jj/> sport where people try to <throw::vb/> a heavy weighted <ball::nn/> as far as they can.
They "put" the <ball::nn/> by holding it at their <neck::body/> and pushing it through the air.
The shot put has been <part::nn/> of the Olympics since 1896.
The weight of the ball can vary from 6 to 16 pounds, depending on age and <gender::nn/> of the participants. The object of the sport is to <throw::vb/> the ball as far as possible.
It is a/an <official::jj/> Olympic event and can be <seen::vbn/> at the Olympic games.
The shot put event was first seen in the Middle Ages, when people would <throw::vb/> cannonballs at their <enemies::nns/>.
It is a/an <outdoor::jj/> event and cannot be played inside.

A game of baseball is played by two teams on a/an <baseball::jj/> field.
Each team has nine <players::nns/>.
There are also <umpires::nns/>.
Umpires watch everything <carefully::rb/> to decide what happened, make calls about a/an <play::nn/>, and make sure everyone follows the <rules::nns/>.
On a/an <baseball::nn/> field, there are four bases.
The bases form a diamond that goes around the <field::nn/> to the right from the starting base.
The starting base is called <home::jj/> plate.
First base is on the <right::jj/> side of the field, second base is at the top of the <infield::nn/>, third base is on the left side of the <field::nn/>, and home plate is at the back.
The game is played in <innings::nns/>.
When one team <bats::vbz/>, the other team plays defense and tries to <get::vb/> three players on the other team out.
After nine innings, the team that has the most <runs::nns/> is the winner.

Angry Birds is a video game franchise, <praised::vbd/> for its <successful::jj/> combination of fun gameplay, <comical::jj/> style, and low price.
Its popularity gave rise to many <spin-offs::nns/>.
Versions of Angry Birds have been created for <PCs::nns/> and gaming consoles, a market for merchandise featuring its <characters::nns/>, a televised cartoon series, and a/an <upcoming::jj/> feature film.
As of July 2015, the games have been <downloaded::vbn/> more than three billion times collectively, making Angry Birds the most <downloaded::jj/> freemium game series of all time.
However, the Angry Birds site was <defaced::vbn/> by hackers who replaced the name with "<Spying::vbg/> Birds".
Soon, Rovio, the company that <created::vbd/> Angry Birds, announced that "The defacement was <caught::vbn/> in minutes and <corrected::vbn/> immediately"

Tesla Motors is a company based in California which <makes::vbz/> electric cars.
Their business idea was to make a very <expensive::jj/>, very good electric <car::nn/>, and <sell::vb/> each one for a lot of <money::nn/>.
Tesla first gained <widespread::jj/> attention following their <production::nn/> of the Roadster, the first fully <electric::jj/> sports car.
Then after they had made some <money::nn/>, they would start making <cars::nns/> that were not expensive, and eventually <make::vb/> cheap electric cars that most people could <buy::vb/>.
So far their <ideas::nns/> have been working, and they are one of the very few start-up companies that have been able to stay in <business::nn/> and <make::vb/> electric cars.

The Boston Tea Party was a/an <violent::jj/> protest by American <colonists::nns/> against King George III's rule in America on December 16, 1773.
The Americans had no one to <speak::vb/> for them in the British government.
They were frustrated that they were being taxed by the <government::nn/> but had no part in how the government was run.
They thought it was not right to pay <taxes::nns/> when they did not have a representative in the government ("No taxation without representation!").
Also merchants <selling::vbg/> their goods would lose their <profit::nn/> because of the taxes.
The Americans began purchasing smuggled <goods::nns/>, which were much <cheaper::jj/>.
To show how angry they were, Samuel Adams and a group of people named the <Sons::nns/> of Liberty dressed up as <Native::jj/> Americans and went onto <ships::nns/> in the Boston Harbor.
They took boxes of tea and dumped them into the <water::liquid/>.

A hot air balloon is a type of <aircraft::nn/>.
It is lifted by <heating::vbg/> the air inside the <balloon::nn/>, usually with fire.
Hot air weighs less than the same volume of cold <air::nn/>, which means that hot air will rise up when there is <cold::jj/> air around it, just like a bubble of air in a pot of <water::liquid/>.
The first <hot::jj/> air balloon to carry a/an <person::nn/> was made by the Montgolfier brothers.
The brothers demonstrated their <invention::nn/> for King Louis XVI and Queen Marie Antoinette at the French <court::nn/> in Paris.
The passengers were a/an <sheep::animal/>, a duck and a/an <rooster::animal/>.
In modern balloons, the <passengers::nns/> and the pilot stand in the <basket::nn/>, which is attached to the balloon by <ropes::nns/>.

Mona Lisa is a/an <famous::jj/> 16th-century portrait painted in <oil::liquid/> by Leonardo da Vinci.
Many people think Mona Lisa's <smile::nn/> is mysterious.
The Louvre Museum says that about 80 percent of its <visitors::nns/> come to <see::vb/> Mona Lisa.
In 1911, when the Mona Lisa was stolen, the Louvre <closed::vbd/> for one week to <look::vb/> for it.
People thought Guillaume Apollinaire, a French <poet::nn/>, stole the painting.
He was put into <jail::nn/>, and he tried to make people think his friend Pablo Picasso did it.
A worker at the Louvre, named Vincenzo Peruggia, had <actually::rb/> stolen it.
He had hidden it in his <coat::nn/> and walked out with it after the <museum::nn/> had closed.
After hiding it in his <apartment::nn/> for two years, he grew <impatient::jj/> and tried to sell it to a/an <gallery::nn/> in Florence, but was caught.

The Venus flytrap is a/an <carnivorous::jj/> plant that <feeds::vbz/> on small animals, such as insects.
Carnivorous plants <grow::vb/> in soil that has little <nitrogen::nn/>.
They get <nitrogen::nn/> from the insects they <trap::vb/>.
The Venus flytrap is one of a very small group of plants that can snap shut very <quickly::rb/>.
When an insect <crawls::vbz/> along the leaves and touches a hair, the <trap::nn/> closes.
The clam-shaped leaves of the plant look rather like <flowers::nns/>, and so they <attract::vb/> insects.
The Venus flytrap feeds on insects, such as <ants::animal_plural/>, beetles, woodlice, worms, flies, <grasshoppers::animal_plural/>, and moths.
First it traps the insect inside its <leaves::nns/>, and then lets out a/an <liquid::liquid/> that helps digest the <trapped::vbn/> animal.

A zombie is a mythical <dead::jj/> person who has returned to <life::nn/> as a walking corpse.
Zombies can walk, think, and <attack::vb/> living persons.
In zombies, the heart, lungs, and a small part of their <brain::body/> still work.
They may react to their <environment::nn/>, but they do not have <consciousness::nn/>.
Zombies can use their <skeleton::body/> and muscles to <move::vb/>.
Zombies are usually covered in <blood::nn/>.
They often have open <wounds::nns/> and are dressed in <ripped::jj/> clothes.
Zombies appear a lot in <horror::jj/> and <fantasy::jj/> films.
Normally, the zombie is a/an <mindless::jj/>, clumsy corpse which eats <human flesh::food/>.
Zombies cannot be called cannibals because they do not <eat::vb/> each other, only <living::jj/> humans.

The Statue of Liberty, officially named Liberty Enlightening the <World::nn/>, is a/an <monument::nn/> symbolizing the United States.
The statue is placed near the entrance to New York City <harbor::nn/>.
The statue commemorates the <signing::nn/> of the United States <Declaration of Independence::nn/>.
It was given to the United States by the <people::nns/> of France, to represent the friendship between the two countries that was <established::vbn/> during the American Revolution.
It represents a/an <woman::nn/> wearing a stola, a/an <crown::nn/> and sandals, trampling a broken <chain::nn/>, and with a torch in her raised right <hand::body/> and a/an <tablet::nn/>, where the date of the Declaration of Independence is written, in her left <hand::body/>.
The statue is on <Liberty::jj/> Island in New York Harbor, and it welcomes visitors, <immigrants::nns/>, and returning Americans traveling by <ship::nn/>.

Squash is a sport in which two players hit a ball with a/an <racket::nn/>.
The aim of the game is to <beat::vb/> the other player by <hitting::vbg/> the front <wall::nn/> and making the <ball::nn/> bounce twice on the floor before they can hit their turn.
Every point is started with a/an <serve::nn/>, which must be hit from a service <box::nn/> on a side of the <court::nn/>.
During play, if one player gets in the way of the other who is <trying::vbg/> to get to the <ball::nn/>, that player can ask the <referee::nn/> for a "<let::nn/>" which results in the point being replayed.
If a player prevents the other player from <swinging::vbg/> at the ball, that player can appeal for a "<stroke::nn/>", which results in the player who could not safely <hit::vb/> the ball winning the <point::nn/>.

Millions of <people::nns/> around the world viewed the launch of Apollo 11 on television.
Richard Nixon, who was the <President::nn/>, watched the <launch::nn/> from the White House.
About two hours after leaving <Earth::nn/> the Lunar Command and Landing Modules separated from the main rocket.
3 days later the crew entered <lunar::jj/> orbit.
A day later the <landing::jj/> section separated from the <command::jj/> module.
The landing module <landed::vbd/> safely on the moon with Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin aboard.
During the landing there were several problems with the mission <computer::nn/> and to avoid a crash Armstrong had to take manual control of the landing craft.
They eventually landed with only 25 seconds of <fuel::nns/> left. Armstrong became the first human to walk and <speak::vb/> on the moon's surface.
The first words he said were: "That is one small step for a/an <man::nn/>, one giant leap for <mankind::nn/>".

Formula One is a type of motorsport.
Teams <compete::vb/> in a series of Grand Prix races, held in different <countries::nns/> around the world.
Some of the most <popular::jj/> races are held in Monaco, Japan, Italy and Britain.
Drivers are paid huge <salaries::nns/> to risk their <lives::nns/> every time they step into the <cockpit::nn/> of the F1 car.
Like all types of motor <racing::nn/>, the dangers associated with Formula One are <great::jj/>.
Therefore, there are many safety <measures::nns/>.
Drivers' helmets are so <strong::jj/> that they can be driven over by <trucks::nns/> with no <damage::nn/> being done to them.
A drop in viewership and <attendance::nn/> figures at races has prompted a number of <rule::nn/> changes in recent years.
These changes are meant to make the <races::nns/> more <interesting::jj/>, so that more people <watch::vb/> F1.

A circus is a/an <special::jj/> entertainment that can be enjoyed by children and <adults::nns/>.
Circuses are a group of <performers::nns/> that may include acrobats, clowns, <trained::jj/> animals, trapeze acts, tightrope walkers, jugglers and other artists who perform <stunts::nns/>.
Circuses <usually::rb/> travel to different parts of the country or to different <countries::nns/>.
They perform in a huge <tent::nn/> called the "<Big::jj/> Top".
There may be room for hundreds of <people::nns/> in the audience.
In the middle is the circular area where the artists <perform::vb/>.
This area is called the "<ring::nn/>".
The person in charge of the whole show is the "ringmaster".
Not all circuses <travel about::vb/>.
A few circuses <perform::vb/> in their own <building::nn/>.

The gods and goddesses in Greek mythology have <special::jj/> parts in the <world::nn/>.
For instance, Zeus is the god of the <sky::nn/>, Poseidon is the <god::nn/> of the sea and Hephaestus is the god of <fire::nn/>.
The gods can make themselves <invisible::vb/> to humans and move to any place in a very <short::jj/> time.
The gods and goddesses never get sick and can only be <hurt::vbn/> by very unusual causes.
This is called being <immortal::nn/>.
Zeus was the <king::nn/> of the gods and <lived::vbd/> with the other gods on top of Mt. Olympus in Greece.
There are lots of monsters in Greek <mythology::nn/>.
Many are hybrids of animals or <people::nns/>.
Some important Greek <monsters::nns/> are minotaurs, satyrs, <centaurs::nns/> and chimera.

Skydiving is a method of <transiting::vbg/> from a high point to Earth with the aid of <gravity::nn/>, involving the control of speed during the descent with a/an <parachute::nn/>.
It can involve free-fall when the <parachute::nn/> is not deployed and the body gradually <accelerates::vbz/> to terminal velocity.
The jump can also be made from a/an <helicopter::nn/> or the bottom of a/an <hot::jj/> air balloon from about 4000 meters.
Skydiving is a/an <exciting::jj/> sport because despite the <perception::nn/> of danger, fatalities are <rare::jj/>.
Approximately one in 750 deployments of a main parachute result in a/an <malfunction::nn/>.
Parachutists often land with <dangerous::jj/> amounts of kinetic energy, and for this reason, improper <landings::nns/> are the cause of more than 30% of all skydiving related <injuries::nns/> and deaths.

Fishing is the activity of trying to <catch::vb/> fish.
Fishing can be done in the <sea::nn/>, or in a lake or river, or from the <shore::nn/>.
Techniques for catching fish include <hand::nn/> gathering, spearing, netting, angling and trapping.
The term fishing may be used for catching other <aquatic::jj/> animals such as <molluscs::animal_plural/> and crustaceans.
The term is not normally used for catching <farmed::jj/> fish.
With aquatic mammals, such as <whales::animal_plural/>, the term <whaling::nn/> is better.
The total number of <commercial::jj/> fishermen and fish farmers is estimated to be 38 million.
Fisheries and <aquaculture::nn/> provide direct and <indirect::jj/> employment to over 500 million people in developing countries.
In addition to <providing::vbg/> food, modern fishing is also a/an <recreational::jj/> sport.

Amazon Mechanical Turk is a crowdsourcing site enabling <individuals::nns/> and businesses to coordinate the use of human intelligence to perform <tasks::nns/> that computers are currently unable to do.
Employers are able to post <jobs::nns/> known as Human Intelligence Tasks (HITs), such as <choosing::vbg/> the best among several photographs of a/an <storefront::nn/>, writing product descriptions, or <identifying::vbg/> performers on music CDs.
The name Mechanical Turk comes from "The Turk", a chess-playing <automaton::nn/> of the 18th century, which was made by Wolfgang von Kempelen.
It was later revealed that this "<machine::nn/>" was not an automaton at all, but was in fact a human <chess::nn/> master hidden in the <cabinet::nn/> beneath.
According to a survey <conducted::vbn/> in 2008, Mechanical Turk workers are <primarily::rb/> located in the United States with demographics generally similar to the overall <Internet::nn/> population in the US.

Superman is one of the most <popular:::jj/> superheroes and is possibly the first modern <superhero::nn/> character.
Superman's father, Jor-El, found out that their <planet::nn/> Krypton was going to <explode:::vb/>.
So, Jor-El sent his baby son to Earth in a/an <spacecraft:::nn/> to save him.
As he grows up, Superman finds out that he has <special:::jj/> powers and he is <invulnerable:::jj/>.
He is strong enough to <lift:::vb/> almost anything, move faster than a/an <bullet:::nn/>, and he can <freeze:::vb/> things with his super-breath.
He decides to use his special powers to <fight::vb/> crime and <save:::vb/> people in danger.
His weaknesses are <radioactive::jj/> rocks from his home planet that are called "kryptonite", and magic.
Kryptonite weakens him so he can not use his <powers::nns/> for a long time, nor can he <move:::vb/>.

Snoring is the <noise::nn/> that people often make when they are <sleeping::vbg/>.
It is often caused by a blocked <nose::body/> or throat.
The noise is often <loud::jj/>, as it is made by <air::nn/> passing through the <nasal::jj/> passages or the <throat::body/>.
Research suggests that snoring is one of the factors of <sleep::nn/> deprivation.
It also causes daytime <drowsiness::nn/>, irritability, and lack of <focus::nn/>.
Snoring can cause significant <psychological::jj/> and social damage to <sufferers::nns/>.
So far, there is no certain <treatment::nn/> available that can <completely::rb/> stop snoring.

Telephone tapping is when somebody listens to <telephone::nn/> calls made by others.
They use a listening device called a/an <bug::nn/> to listen to and <record::vb/> the conversation so that another <person::nn/> can then listen to it <later::rb/>.
This is illegal in many <countries::nns/> because it means that telephone calls are not <private::jj/>.
Sometimes, the police <tap::vb/> telephone calls to <catch::vb/> terrorists or other <criminals::nns/>.
For example, the Watergate scandal <happened::vbd/> when United States <President::nn/> Richard Nixon was tied to a crime in which <former::jj/> FBI and CIA agents broke into the <offices::nns/> of the Democratic Party and George McGovern, the Presidential candidate.
Nixon's helpers listened to phone lines and <secret::jj/> papers were stolen.

Batman is a fictional character and one of the most <famous::jj/> superheroes.
He was the second <superhero::nn/> to be created, after Superman.
Batman began in comic books and he was later <used::vbn/> in several movies, TV programs, and books.
Batman lives in the <fictional::jj/> city of Gotham.
When he is not in <costume::nn/>, he is Bruce Wayne, a very <rich::jj/> businessman.
Batman's origin story is that as a/an <young::jj/> child, Bruce Wayne saw a robber <murder::vb/> his parents after the family left a/an <theater::nn/>.
Bruce decided that he did not want that kind of <violence::nn/> to happen to anyone else.
He dedicated his life to <protect::vb/> Gotham City.
Wayne learned many different ways to <fight::vb/> as he grew up.
As an adult, he wore a/an <costume::nn/> to protect his <identity::nn/> while fighting <crime::nn/> in Gotham.

A beauty contest is a/an <public::jj/> contest to decide which <person::nn/> is the most <beautiful::jj/>.
Usually, the entrants are <young::jj/> females, but there are some contests for <men::nns/>.
Each contest has its own <rules::nns/> as to who may <enter::vb/>, and what the <prizes::nns/> are.
Usually the contests are held to create <publicity::nn/> for the organization which <runs::vbz/> the contest.
The contests are often shown on <television::nn/> and reported in newspapers.
With most contests the criteria for judging is <physical::jj/> appearance, plus some judgement of <personality::nn/>.
The winner is often described as a Beauty <Queen::nn/>.

Ducks are birds, closely related to swans and <geese::animal_plural/>.
The main difference is that ducks have shorter <necks::body_plural/>, and ducks are smaller.
Most ducks are <aquatic::jj/> birds, they can be found in both saltwater and fresh <water::liquid/>.
Ducks are omnivorous, eating <aquatic::jj/> plants and tiny <animals::nns/>.
Some ducks are not <wild::jj/>, and they are bred and kept by <humans::nns/>.
They are kept to provide <food::food/>, or to use their <feathers::body_plural/> for pillows.
Especially in Asia, many people like to <eat::vb/> ducks.
Ducks are often kept by groups of <people::nns/> on public ponds for their beauty and <calming::jj/> nature.
People commonly feed ducks in ponds stale <bread::nn/>, thinking that the ducks will like to have something to <eat::vb/>, but this is not healthy for ducks and can <kill::vb/> them.

Cats are the most <popular::jj/> pets in the world.
They were probably first kept because they ate <mice::animal_plural/>.
Later cats were <kept::vbn/> because they are <friendly::jj/> and they are good <companions::nns/>.
Cats are active carnivores, meaning they hunt <live::jj/> prey.
They mainly prey on small mammals, like <mice::animal_plural/>.
Their main method of <hunting::vbg/> is stalk and <pounce::vb/>.
While dogs have great <stamina::nn/> and they will <chase::vb/> prey over long distances, cats are extremely <fast::jj/>, but only over short distances.
The cat creeps towards a chosen victim, keeping its <body::nn/> flat and near to the <ground::nn/> so that it cannot be <seen::vbn/> easily, until it is close enough for a rapid <dash::nn/> or pounce.

Facebook is a/an <social::jj/> networking service and <website::nn/>.
In Facebook, users may make a personal <profile::nn/>, add other users as <friends::nns/>, and send <messages::nns/>.
Facebook users must <register::vb/> before using the site.
Users may <join::vb/> groups for a workplace or other interest such as <school::nn/>. 
Facebook allows any users who say they are at least 13 years old to become <users::nns/> of the website.
Facebook has been involved in <many::jj/> controversies over <privacy::nn/>.
Some of these controversies have been about <people::animal_plural/> being able to see <personal::jj/> information that other people <post::vb/>, and others are about <companies::nns/> and advertisers being able to <see::vb/> users' personal information.

Advertising is how a company <encourages::vbz/> people to buy their products, services or <ideas::nns/>.
An advertisement is anything that draws <good::jj/> attention towards these things.
It is usually designed by an advertising agency for a/an <sponsor::nn/>, and performed through a variety of <media::nns/>.
Companies use ads to try to get people to <buy::vb/> their products, by showing them the good rather than the bad of their <products::nns/>.
For example, to make a/an <burger::food/> look tasty in advertising, it may be painted with brown food colors, sprayed with <waterproofing::nn/> to prevent it from going <soggy::jj/>, and sesame seeds may be super-glued in place.
Advertising can bring new <customers::nns/> and more sales for a business.
Advertising can be <expensive::jj/> but can help make a business make more <money::nn/>.

Scuba Diving is a sport where people can swim under <water::liquid/> for a long time, using a tank filled with compressed <air::nn/>.
The tank is a/an <large::jj/> cylinder made of steel or <aluminum::nn/>.
A scuba diver <moves::vbz/> underwater by using fins attached to the <feet::body_plural/>.
They also use <equipment::nn/> such as a dive mask to <improve::vb/> underwater vision and equipment to control <buoyancy::nn/>.
A person must take a/an <certification::nn/> class before going scuba diving.
This proves that they have been trained on how to <use::vb/> the equipment and dive <safely::rb/>.
Some tourist attractions have a/an <short::jj/> course on certification and then the instructors <lead::vb/> the class in a/an <shallow::jj/> dive, all in one day.

Valentine's Day is a/an <holiday::nn/> that happens on February 14.
It is the day of the year when lovers show their <love::nn/> to each other.
This can be done by giving <chocolates::food_plural/>, flowers, Valentine's cards or just a/an <nice::jj/> gift.
Some people <pick::vb/> one person and call them their "Valentine" as a gesture to show <love::nn/> and appreciation.
Valentine's Day is named for the <martyred::jj/> Christian saint named Valentine.
He was a bishop who performed <weddings::nns/> for couples who were not allowed to get married because their <parents::nns/> did not agree with the connection or because the bridegroom was a soldier or a/an <slave::nn/>, so the marriage was <forbidden::vbn/>.
Valentine gave the married couple flowers from his <garden::nn/>.
That is why flowers play a very <important::jj/> role on Valentine's Day.
This did not <please::vb/> the emperor, and Valentine was <beheaded::vbn/> because of his Christian <faith::nn/>.

Snoring is the <noise::nn/> that people often make when they are <sleeping::vbg/>.
It is often caused by a blocked <nose::body/> or throat.
The noise is often <loud::jj/>, as it is made by <air::nn/> passing through the <nasal::jj/> passages or the <throat::body/>.
Research suggests that snoring is one of the factors of <sleep::nn/> deprivation.
It also causes daytime <drowsiness::nn/>, irritability, and lack of <focus::nn/>.
Snoring can cause significant <psychological::jj/> and social damage to <sufferers::nns/>.
So far, there is no certain <treatment::nn/> available that can <completely::rb/> stop snoring.

Telephone tapping is when somebody listens to <telephone::nn/> calls made by others.
They use a listening device called a/an <bug::nn/> to listen to and <record::vb/> the conversation so that another <person::nn/> can then listen to it <later::rb/>.
This is illegal in many <countries::nns/> because it means that telephone calls are not <private::jj/>.
Sometimes, the police <tap::vb/> telephone calls to <catch::vb/> terrorists or other <criminals::nns/>.
For example, the Watergate scandal <happened::vbd/> when United States <President::nn/> Richard Nixon was tied to a crime in which <former::jj/> FBI and CIA agents broke into the <offices::nns/> of the Democratic Party and George McGovern, the Presidential candidate.
Nixon's helpers listened to phone lines and <secret::jj/> papers were stolen.

The Olympic Games are a/an <important::jj/> international event featuring summer and winter <sports::nns/>.
Olympic Games are <held::vbn/> every four years, with Summer and Winter Olympic Games taking turns.
Originally, the <ancient::jj/> Olympic Games were <held::vbn/> in Ancient Greece at Olympia.
Over time the Olympics have become <bigger::jj/>.
In old times, <women::nns/> were not allowed to <compete::vb/>, but now everyone is allowed.
The Winter Games were <created::vbn/> for ice and snow <sports::nns/>.
The celebration of the Games includes many <rituals::nns/> and symbols, such as the Olympic flag and <torch::nn/>, as well as the opening and closing ceremonies.
The first, second, and third place finishers in each event <receive::vb/>, respectively, gold, silver, and bronze <medals::nns/>.

In golf, a golfer <plays::vbz/> a number of <holes::nns/> in a given order.
Golfers put the ball on a small <stand::nn/> called a tee and swing a/an <club::nn/> at it to hit it as straight and far as possible.
The "green" is the <area::nn/> near the hole where the <grass::nn/> is cut very short.
Once on the green, the <players::nns/> will try to "put" the <ball::nn/> into the hole.
"Putting" is similar to a/an <regular::jj/> swing except it is not as hard and the player does not want the ball to go in the <air::nn/>.
Each time a player <swings::vbz/> at his <ball::nn/>, it is considered a/an "<stroke::nn/>".
Each hole has a certain number of <strokes::nns/> that golfers are expected to <need::vb/> to get their ball into the hole.
The golfer with the smallest number of <strokes::nns/> all together <wins::vbz/>.

Godzilla is a/an <giant::jj/> dinosaur-like fictional monster who first appeared in <movies::nns/> from Japan.
Since then Godzilla has become a/an <worldwide::jj/> pop culture icon, appearing in numerous media including video games, <novels::nns/>, comic books, and films.
Some stories portrayed Godzilla as a/an <antihero::nn/> while other plots portrayed him as a destructive <monster::nn/>; sometimes the lesser of two threats who <plays::vbz/> the defender but is still a/an <danger::nn/> to humanity.
During his movie career, this <large::jj/> reptile fought against many monsters, including the <giant::jj/> moth-like Mothra, the three-headed King Ghidorah, and several more <enemies::nns/>.
Godzilla has even fought against fictional <characters::nns/> from other <franchises::nns/> in crossover media, such as King Kong and the <Fantastic::jj/> Four.

Elephants are the <largest::jj/> living land mammals.
An elephant's most obvious part is the <trunk:::body/>.
An elephant uses its trunk to grab objects such as <food:::food/>.
Though the rest of an elephant's hide is <strong::jj/> and thick, its trunk is very <soft::jj/> and <sensitive::jj/>.
The elephant usually stands <still::rb/>, raises its trunk, and blows, which is a signal to <elephants:::animal_plural/> and wildlife.
Their ways of acting toward other <elephants:::animal_plural/> are hard for <people:::animal/> to understand.
Most elephant sounds are so <low::jj/> that people cannot hear them, but elephants can hear these sounds far away.
Elephants also have <tusks:::body/> coming out of their upper jaws.
A lot of ivory comes from elephant tusks.
Ivory traders killed many elephants, so <hunting::vbg/> them is now illegal.

Jeopardy is a/an <American::jj/> television game show that features a quiz competition.
Unlike regular trivia games, the <answers::nns/> are given as clues, and players come up with <questions::nns/> as an answer.
For example, a clue would be "he was our first <president::nn/>", and the right answer would be "who is George Washington?"
In the <first::jj/> round, there are six <categories::nns/> with five clues in each, each worth between $200 to $1000.
The final Jeopardy round is made up of just one <category::nn/> and one <clue::nn/>.
During the <commercial::jj/> break, players write their <wagers::nns/> based on their knowledge of the given category.
After the commercial break, the <host::nn/> reads the clue.
The players have 30 seconds to <write::vb/> their answers, again in the form of a/an <question::nn/>.
The player with the most <money::nns/> at the end of the game <keeps::vbz/> his or her winnings and comes back to the <next::jj/> show.

Beyonce is an American singer, songwriter, record producer and <actress::nn/>.
Born and raised in Houston, Texas, she <performed::vbd/> in various singing and <dancing::vbg/> competitions as a/an <child::nn/> and rose to fame in the late 1990s as <lead::jj/> singer of R&B girl-group <Destiny::nn/>'s Child.
Managed by her father, Mathew Knowles, the group became one of the world's <best-selling::jj/> girl groups of all time.
Their hiatus saw the release of Beyonce's debut album, <Dangerously::rb/> in Love (2003), which <established::vbd/> her as a/an <solo::nn/> artist worldwide, and earned five Grammy <Awards::nns/>.
Her performances have led some <critics::nns/> to consider her one of the greatest <entertainers::nns/> in contemporary <popular::jj/> music.

Penguins are very <friendly::jj/> animals.
Penguins cannot <fly::vb/>, but they can swim very well.
They have <good::jj/> hearing and can see underwater.
All penguins have a white <belly::body/> and a dark back.
The white and black <colors::nns/> are for camouflage when they swim.
When a/an <predator::animal/> looking from underwater sees the <white::jj/> belly and wings of the penguin, it can not <see::vb/> the penguin well with the light coming from above.
The biggest penguins may stand nearly 4 feet tall and can weigh almost 100 pounds.
Penguins have a thick layer of <blubber::nn/> that helps them keep <warm::jj/>, and their feathers are very <tightly::rb/> packed to make another cover.
They also have a layer of woolly down under the feathers that are coated with a type of <oil::liquid/> that makes them <water::liquid/>-proof.

Pokemon Go is a free-to-play <smartphone::nn/> game.
The game lets players <capture::vb/>, train and <fight::vb/> machine-based living beings, called Pokemon.
The game makes them seem as though Pokemons exist in real life by using <GPS::nn/> and the smart phone's <camera::nn/>.
As players walk in the real world, their <character::nn/> in the game moves as well.
Players can find <Pokemon::nn/> by using the game map.
They can then throw a Pokeball at the Pokemon to see if they can <catch::vb/> it.
In the game, players can also walk to <special::jj/> places called "PokeStops" or "Gyms".
At PokeStops, players can find <extra::jj/> PokeBalls and <candy::nn/> to feed their Pokemon.
At Gyms, players can get their Pokemon to <fight::vb/> another Pokemon to try to win that gym for their <team::nn/>.

In 2001, Fuller, Cowell, and TV producer Simon Jones attempted to <sell::vb/> the Pop Idol format to the United States, but the <idea::nn/> was met with <poor::jj/> response from United States <television::nn/> networks.
However, Rupert Murdoch, head of Fox's parent company, was persuaded to <buy::vb/> the show by his <daughter::nn/> Elisabeth, who was a/an <fan::nn/> of the British show.
The show was renamed American Idol: The Search for a <superstar::nn/> and debuted in 2002.
Much to Cowell's surprise, it became one of the <hit::jj/> shows for the summer that year.
With the personal engagement of the viewers with the <contestants::nns/> through voting, and the presence of the <acid-tongued::jj/> Cowell as a judge, the show grew into a/an <phenomenon::nn/>.
By 2004, it had become the <most-watched::jj/> show in the U.S., a position it then held on for seven consecutive <seasons::nns/>.

The average earthworm is a reddish brown color, with a/an <pointed::jj/> posterior and anterior end.

Valentine's Day is a/an <holiday::nn/> that happens on February 14.
It is the day of the year when lovers show their <love::nn/> to each other.
This can be done by giving <chocolates::food_plural/>, flowers, Valentine's cards or just a/an <nice::jj/> gift.
Some people <pick::vb/> one person and call them their "Valentine" as a gesture to show <love::nn/> and appreciation.
Valentine's Day is named for the <martyred::jj/> Christian saint named Valentine.
He was a bishop who performed <weddings::nns/> for couples who were not allowed to get married because their <parents::nns/> did not agree with the connection or because the bridegroom was a soldier or a/an <slave::nn/>, so the marriage was <forbidden::vbn/>.
Valentine gave the married couple flowers from his <garden::nn/>.
That is why flowers play a very <important::jj/> role on Valentine's Day.
This did not <please::vb/> the emperor, and Valentine was <beheaded::vbn/> because of his Christian <faith::nn/>.
